abstracts.cdata!:
The urban Infrastructure Services
            Development Project for Colombia had the following ratings:
            the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely,
            the institutional development impact was substantial, and
            the Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            The lessons learned indicate that Financiera de Desarrollo
            Territorial (FINDETER) continues to be a development bank of
            fundamental importance in developing the municipal and urban
            services market. At the time the project was formulated
            (1996-97), municipal finance in Colombia was expanding
            rapidly, and longer terms with funding from local financial
            markets seemed imminent. Although private participation was
            mainly concentrated in 2 or 3 sectors in this project, its
            role has proved important in accomplishing the main outcomes
            of the project, and crucial in increasing loan volume in
            response to the crisis. FINDETER has played an important
            role in traditional sectors as water and sanitation,
            education and transport. Although automatic rediscounting
            has proved to be an excellent lending instrument, FINDETER
            should improve this mechanism, partly by learning from other
            second-floor banks' automatic rediscounting. The
            project has demonstrated the need for flexibility, financial
            innovation and continuous learning under the complex
            framework of the economy. Close Bank involvement as part of
            the FINDETER team clearly made important contributions to
            the organization and the operation during the eventful
            period of the project (1997 to mid 2004).
